Award.AwardTitle: Lava-Substrate Interactions: Numerical and Experimental Investigations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Elise Rumpf has been granted a National Science Foundation (NSF) Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University. She will study the effects of substrate composition, grain size, and roughness on the emplacement of lava flows. Lava heat loss and motion are influenced by thermal and mechanical interactions with the underlying substrate, which can affect the mobility, duration, extent and morphology of an active lava flow. This work will enhance the current understanding of lava flow emplacement and lava flow hazards by quantifying substrate influence on lava flow morphology and advance rate. Results will be used to improve existing models that predict the paths of lava flows to reduce potential threats to property, agriculture, and local infrastructure in communities living near active volcanoes. The knowledge gained through this project will also be applicable to lava flows on other planets and moons in our Solar System providing key information on past environmental conditions and planetary thermal evolution. This project will be used to educate the public about lava flows and their hazards. In addition to mentoring undergraduate and graduate students through internships and lectures at Columbia University, Dr. Rumpf will invite the public to view lava pour events and lava-analog experiments in person or through webcasts.

Lava morphology and emplacement are complex processes influenced by thermal and mechanical interactions with the underlying substrate. Substrate roughness may affect the mobility of a lava flow directly, by acting as either a barrier or a conduit, or more subtly, as flow irregularities may develop at the lava-substrate boundary. The thermal conductivity of a substrate, dependent on composition and grain size, can affect lava flow heat loss, and thus influence the duration a flow is active. This project will focus on improving our knowledge of these interactions through: 1) Experiments using polyethylene glycol wax as an analog to lava flows to obtain initial estimates of the effects of substrate roughness on lava emplacement; 2) Experiments in which molten basalt will be poured onto a variety of substrates to determine relationships between flow behavior and heat loss and substrate type; 3) Numerical simulations replicating experimental results and expanded conditions to predict emplacement environments found on other planetary bodies; and 4) A survey of the roughness and topography at volcanic regions on the Earth, the Moon, and Mars to improve lava flow prediction methods on Earth and advance our understanding of planetary volcanic evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This two-year project supported a postdoctoral fellow at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University in studying the effects of small-scale topography (less than the height of the flow) on lava flow emplacement. The results demonstrate that small-scale topography, or substrate roughness, does have an effect on lava flow front advance rate. Increasing roughness of the substrate decreased flow advance rate. This understanding will improve models used by volcanologists and emergency managers to predict lava flow pathways and inundation rates to better prepare communities for potential damage caused by active lava flows.

The project developed three sets of analog experiments to study the effects of substrate roughness on flow emplacement, each using a different material: corn syrup, polyethylene glycol (PEG), and molten basalt. In each of the experiments, the fluid material was extruded onto a sloped surface covered in bedding with systematically varied grain sizes. Flows were monitored for length, thickness, surface area, and temperature (where applicable) as they were emplaced. Experiments showed that as substrate roughness increases, flow front velocity decreases, and that this relationship diminishes over time. The primary reason for this decrease in velocity is the movement of material into pore spaces between substrate grains. This results in decreased volume, and therefore decreased velocity, of the material moving downslope. With time, a thermal and mechanical boundary layer develops at the base, diminishing this effect. Using project results, we determined a “roughness factor” that modifies existing flow emplacement equations that can be calibrated to account for natural emplacement substrates. The addition of this factor to flow emplacement models will increase the accuracy to which lava emplacement can be predicted. Additionally, experiments showed that increasing substrate grain size increases the complexity of the flow outline, indicating that complex natural surfaces may increase variability in lava flow emplacement pathways.

Our work also demonstrated the usefulness of unmanned aerial systems (UASs) in volcanological fieldwork. We used UASs to map and characterize lava flow morphology, roughness, and underlying substrate type at lava flows at Holuhraun Flow Field, Iceland, and Quizapu Volcano, Chile. The field methods we developed and the analysis of data collected showed that UASs offer a cost-effective and time-efficient tool for collecting data for creating topographic and geologic maps.

An additional, and very rewarding, aspect of this project was the chance to work with student scientists in the completion of their first research projects. During this fellowship period, four undergraduate and three high school students actively participated in the development and completion of this project’s experiments. Of these seven students, six of them were female. This provided a rewarding chance to bring fresh ideas into the lab and to train the next generation of Earth scientists. This project also allowed for the development of an exciting outreach activity called “Save the Village!” This activity requires the participants to build barriers to block a wax “lava” flow from destroying a toy “village,” exposing them to volcanic hazards, lava flow behavior, and to the types of decision making required of emergency managers. We carried out this activity at the World Science Festival in New York City and at the LDEO Annual Open House. Several thousand members of the public attended each event.
